stem: An 8-year-old child is 4 hours post-reduction of a supracondylar humerus fracture. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute pain and sensory loss in a child's hand.
Background: Supracondylar humerus fracture (Left). Rigid cast applied.
Assessment: Child reports 'I can't feel my fingers' and is crying inconsolably.
Recommendation: Immediate evaluation for compartment syndrome (Volkmann's).

tabs.title: Neurovascular Assessment Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
PainSevere (10/10); Not relieved by morphineIschemic Pain
Finger ExtensionAgonizing pain with passive stretchClassic Early Sign
Distal PulseRadial pulse is weak and threadyCompromised perfusion
Capillary Refill5 secondsDelayed

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 112/70, HR 128 (Tachycardia from pain), RR 24. Hand is cold and pale.

actionOptions.text: Position the affected arm at the level of the heart
Immediately notify the orthopedic surgeon and bivalve the cast
Elevate the arm above the level of the heart to reduce edema
Apply heat packs to the fingers to promote vasodilation

parameterOptions.text: Continuous neurovascular checks (6 Ps) every 15–30 minutes
Sensation and motor function in the hand/fingers
Daily measurement of serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Acute Compartment Syndrome (c2) (specifically Volkmann's Ischemia, which refers to the forearm compartment following an elbow fracture). Key indicators: Pain out of proportion, pain with passive stretch, and sensory loss. Priority #1 is lowering the pressure by bivalving the cast (a2) (notifying the surgeon), and Priority #2 is maintaining perfusion by keeping the arm at heart level (a1) (never elevate). Management focus is on the 6 Ps (p1) and motor/sensory recovery (p2).
clinicalPearls: Supracondylar humerus fractures are the classic pediatric trigger for Volkmann's.
Ischemic contracture occurs within 6–12 hours of the blockage, leading to permanent claw-like hands if untreated.
The 'Passive Stretch' test is the most important clinical exam for this condition.

questionTrap.trap: Elevating the arm to treat the 'swelling' after a fracture.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: When the pain is 10/10 and the capillary refill is slow, it is no longer just swelling; it is ischemia. Do not elevate! Elevation reduces arterial pressure and makes the ischemia worse.

mnemonic.title: Volkmann's Warning
mnemonic.expansion: V-Very much pain. O-Ouch with stretching. L-Loss of pulse (Late). K-Killer muscle pressure.
